study_plan_entry.title: A guided tour for engineers in applied stochastic modelling

en.title: A guided tour for engineers in applied stochastic modelling

free_text.Contenu: 1) queuing networks roamed by passive items  and/or  intelligent agents (i.e. traffic of cars, production pallets and pedestrians, hedging stocks in supply chains, buffered flows in manufacturing lines), [br/]2) optimal stochastic control, (optimal task scheduling, optimal target seeking, optimal buffering, optimal queueing policies), [br/]3) multi-agents systems, (swarms dynamics, flocking transitions, synchronization and consensus formation),  [br/]4) noise induced transport and stochastic resonance, (Brownian motors, ratchets, dithering).[br/][br/]The relevant mathematical  tools, namely:  Brownian motion, diffusion processes,  Markov chains,  random velocity evolutions,  stochastic dynamic programming and differential  games, will be progressively exposed to sustain the specific applications under study.  A strong attention will be paid to keep the formalism in its simplest possible setting and all concepts will be illustrated by explicitly solved examples.
free_text.Forme du contrôle: To familiarize  the  students  to  the "art"  of devising stylized models of complex  actual situations, one project to be completed by small teams of participants, (two to three  students per team) will complement the theoretical lectures.  The  project main  themes will be chosen to match the specific interests of the participants. The final grade will be a combination of an individual oral examination  together with the quality of the team project.
free_text.Objectifs d'apprentissage: The goal of this lecture is  to exhibit, via engineering illustrations, how stochastic modeling is  currently used in applied contexts like manufacturing and general traffic flows, oscillators synchronization and nonlinear dynamical systems,  self-organization and consensus formation  in assemblies of  autonomous robotics.
